story.text: NEW YORK Jan 2 U.S. government bond prices edged up on Tuesday in muted trade during a session shortened for a day of mourning to honor former U.S. President Gerald Ford. Many trading desks were thinly staffed as financial markets were either closed or open only for a half-session on Tuesday, when the United States holds a national funeral service for the former president. The Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association has recommended an early bond market close at 2 p.m. (1900 GMT) and the key manufacturing report of the week, the Institute for Supply Management (ISM)'s index was rescheduled for Wednesday. That leaves Tuesday virtually devoid of economic data for bond investors. The manufacturing report on Wednesday and the monthly nonfarm payrolls report, due on Friday, could be major catalysts for the Treasury market. "Given the proximity of ISM and nonfarm payrolls we deem it reasonable to be neutral at current levels, albeit with a bit of a negative bias due to the evident technical damage incurred last month," wrote David Ader, head of government bond strategy with RBS Greenwich Capital in Greenwich, Connecticut. The 10-year note's yield -- which moves inversely to its price -- jumped to 4.70 percent at the end of December from 4.46 percent at the start of last month. On Tuesday, benchmark 10-year notes US10YT=RR edged up 1/32 in price for a yield of 4.70 percent, versus 4.70 percent late on Friday. Markets had been closed on Monday for the New Year's Day public holiday. Two-year notes US2YT=RR -- which respond closely to expectations for Federal Reserve interest rate moves -- inched up 1/32 in price to yield 4.80 percent, compared with 4.82 percent on Friday. The Treasury market "is opening up stronger, reversing some of the weakness of last week," wrote Andrew Brenner, head of global fixed-income at Hapoalim Securities in New York in a daily research note on Tuesday. Last week, stronger-than-expected U.S. economic reports weighed on bond prices as prospects of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut early this year appeared to dwindle. "The November data, at least, reinforces the idea the Fed's on hold," Ader wrote. Home sales, consumer confidence and a Chicago manufacturing index all exceeded market forecasts. Prospects for the Fed to lower rates by June, as shown by short-term U.S. interest rate futures, had fallen to about 58 percent late on Friday after being fully priced as recently as Dec. 21. Further insight into the Federal Reserve's thinking may come from the release on Wednesday of the minutes from its last monetary policy meeting on Dec 12. (Additional reporting by Kirsten Donovan in London)
story.title: treasuries - prices edge up in shortened session
